I look forward to improving antitrust enforcement this Congress. It is imperative that we ensure markets work for consumers, not just monopolists. It is equally imperative that we not cede this task to the radical left. The consumer welfare standard is essential to both. 5/5

We need the enforcers to (finally) enforce the antitrust laws against those who harm competition and consumers, including Big Tech. But we need to do it in a way that doesn't allow judges to usurp Congress's legislative role. 4/5

Let's also note what the consumer welfare standard is NOT: it is not a narrow concern with price. As Judge Bork wrote, it encompasses “innovation, choice among differing products" and quality. That more than covers the ways in which markets like Big Tech are failing us. 3/5

What is the consumer welfare standard? It's a guardrail that ensures 1) the primary beneficiaries of the antitrust laws are the people, not big business; and 2) that unelected judges are not allowed to use antitrust to advance their own political preferences. 2/5

There’s a lot of talk about antitrust legislation this Congress. One thing lost in many proposed reforms: the consumer welfare standard is not a get-out-of-jail-free card for Big Tech. We don’t need to change the law, we need to enforce it. 1/5
I’d otherwise share this on Parler too, but ....
